title: 114_hr5480
content: The "Boosting Equity for the American Middle Class Act of 2016" or the "BEAM Act of 2016" introduces a refundable credit for early principal payments on certain home mortgages under section 36C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "BEAM Act of 2016" introduces a credit for excess home mortgage principal payments made by individuals, limited to 50% of the payments and capped at $500 annually. There is also a lifetime limitation of 10 years and a reduction based on modified adjusted gross income. The "BEAM Act of 2016" allows a credit for excess home mortgage principal payments, limited to 50% of payments and capped at $500 annually. The credit is reduced based on modified adjusted gross income. The "BEAM Act of 2016" offers a credit for excess home mortgage principal payments, limited to 50% of payments and capped at $500 annually. Qualified home mortgage indebtedness refers to acquisition debt on the taxpayer's primary residence, meeting traditional mortgage criteria. The "BEAM Act of 2016" provides a credit for excess home mortgage principal payments, limited to 50% of payments and capped at $500 annually. Qualified home mortgage indebtedness must be on the taxpayer's primary residence and meet traditional mortgage criteria, including a term of 15-30 years with equal payments at regular intervals. Married individuals filing separately are not eligible for the credit. The "BEAM Act of 2016" provides a credit for excess home mortgage principal payments, limited to 50% of payments and capped at $500 annually. Married individuals filing separately are not eligible for the credit. Joint returns must be filed for the credit to be allowed, and if claimed, it is treated as allowed to both spouses. Amendments are made to reporting requirements and conforming amendments in the Internal Revenue Code. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years ending after the enactment of this Act.
